newsitem.title: USA: US newspapers seen enjoying benefits of austerity.
newsitem.headline: US newspapers seen enjoying benefits of austerity.

text.p: The U.S. newspaper industry is enjoying a lift in quarterly profits from austerity measures meant to defend against rising raw-material prices, and the benefits are expected to extend into 1997.

"All the cost cuts put in place six to nine months ago -- the smaller news holes, the narrow margins and staff reductions -- are going right to the bottom line," said media analyst Rita Zanella of Gruntal & Co.
Prices for newsprint, the raw material used in newspapers, peaked at $743 a ton in January after a swift rise that dragged down industry profitability.

Publishers reacted by conserving newsprint. Some reduced their news holes -- the pages dedicated to news stories -- or eliminated unprofitable subscribers. Other newspapers trimmed the white margins on each page. Some jobs were lost, too.
But newsprint prices now average about $550 and are forecast to average between $550 and $600 through the end of 1997, analysts said.
"Costs look pretty good," said Prudential Securities analyst James Marsh.
The drop in newsprint prices gave both Times Mirror and Tribune Co a big lift in the third quarter because of their inventory accounting, Marsh said.
Times Mirror reported earnings of $0.43 a share, compared with a loss of $2.98 in the third quarter last year and $0.07 more than the consenus of Wall Street forecasts.
Tribune posted earnings of $1.00 a share, $0.21 more than the 1995 third quarter and $0.15 more than the consensus forecast.
For other big companies, such as Knight-Ridder, the benefits will come later this year and in early 1997, Marsh said.
Gannett Co, the biggest U.S. publisher which recently added broadcast properties, reported earnings of $0.82 a share, up from $0.64 a year ago and in line with the consensus forecast.
Marsh said several newspaper companies had stronger revenues than expected, reflecting healthy rises in classified advertising.
